section.title: Overview
section.para: Commons Persistence is an abstract layer upon the data base and the domain model. If you're using an ORM, It aims to be upon it too making the application independent from the ORM used and each of their particular characteristics. What's more, its main purpose is to lower the data access complexity.
Commons Persistence can be divided in:

listitem.para: Api: uselful interfaces when persisting an object.
Closures: handling transactions by theyself executing a closure in between
Interceptors: adding functionality to the existents from Spring like logging

section.title: Identifiable
section.para: Identifiable represents a persistent object identified by a primary key. Here is the simple API it provides. You can implement the id as you wish.

section.title: Nameable
section.para: Nameable represents a persistent object with id and name.

section.title: Creation Auditable
section.para: Creation Auditable must be implemented by those entities that require creation audit

section.title: Modifiable
section.para: Modifiable must be implemented by entities that can be modified, it defines the object version.

section.title: Modification Auditable
section.para: Modification Auditable must be implemented by entities that require modification audit.

section.title: Logically Deleteable
section.para: Logically Deleteable must be implemented by entities that can be logically deleted

section.title: Closures
section.para: We've implemented some clases to wrap any piece of code execution between a transaction as the Spring OpenSessionInViewFilter does.

listitem.para: OpenEntityManagerClosure: receives the EntityManagerFactory that will create the EntityManager to operate with, the Closure to execute between the transaction and a dryrun parameter that indicates whether to manage a new transaction or just execute the closure without any new context (this is typically the case of test context which already provides a transaction management itself):
listitem.programlisting: public OpenEntityManagerClosure(final EntityManagerFactory emf, final Closure<T> target, final boolean dryrun);

listitem.para: OpenEntityManagerRunnable: uses the OpenEntityManagerClosure but executes a new thread instead of any other Closure. Does not provide a way to do dryrun:
listitem.programlisting: public OpenEntityManagerRunnable(final EntityManagerFactory emf, final Runnable target);

listitem.para: OpenSessionClosure: is exactly like OpenEntityManagerClosure but instead of using the EntityManager, works directly with Hibernate Session:
listitem.programlisting: public OpenSessionClosure(final SessionFactory sessionFactory, final Closure<T> target, final boolean dryrun);

section.title: Utils
section.para: We introduce some utils classes related to object persistence:

listitem.para: ScrollableResultIterator: an iterator that works with Hibernate ScrollableResult.

next returns the actual element and advances next element after that to prepare the following actual element (the constructor initializes the actual element with the first in ScrollableResult). It evicts from Hibernate session the next element to return at the following next if there's any. If there're no more elements, method next assigns the actual element null and in the following called returns NoSuchElementException.
hasNext returns whether the actual element poped out from the ScrollableResult is null.
remove is not implemented by now.

AnonymousAuthenticationUserMapper: does not depend from commons-auth, so users are not managed by Acegi. Therefore, It's used for testing and batch context where there's no need to have users. It has no roles, anonymous is set to false and it only sets the name passed as a parameter when the entity is created.
